```markdown
\large 
The random variable \( Y = \log X \) has \( N(10, 4) \) distribution. Find:
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item The pdf of \( X \)
\item Mean and variance of \( X \)
\item \( P(X \leq 1000) \)
\end{enumerate}

\begin{framed}
A lognormal distribution is a continuous probability distribution of a random variable whose logarithm is normally distributed. Thus, if the random variable \( X \) is log-normally distributed, then \( Y = \ln(X) \) has a normal distribution. Equivalently, if \( Y \) has a normal distribution, then the exponential function of \( Y \), \( X = \exp(Y) \), has a log-normal distribution.
\begin{itemize}
\item Probability Density Function: 
\[ f(x) = \frac{1}{x\sigma \sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left( -\frac{(\ln x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2} \right) \text{ for } x > 0 \]
\item Mean: 
\[ \exp \left( \mu + \frac{\sigma^2}{2} \right) \]
\item Variance: 
\[ \left[ \exp(\sigma^2) - 1 \right] \exp(2\mu + \sigma^2) \]
\end{itemize}
\end{framed}

\textbf{Solution}

\textbf{Part (a)}

\[
f(x) = 
\begin{cases}
\frac{1}{2x \sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp\left( -\frac{(\ln x - 10)^2}{8} \right) & x \geq 0 \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}
\]

\textbf{Part (b)}

\[
E(X) = \exp \left( \mu_Y + \frac{\sigma_Y^2}{2} \right) \\
= e^{10 + 2} \\
= e^{12} \\
\approx 162.754
\]

\[
\operatorname{Var}(X) = \left[ \exp(\sigma_Y^2) - 1 \right] \exp(2\mu_Y + \sigma_Y^2) \\
= (e^4 - 1) \times \exp(24) \\
= (e^4 - 1) e^{24} \\
\approx 53.598 \times e^{24}
\]


---

\textbf{Part (c)}

\[
P(X \leq 1000) \\
= P(\log X \leq \log 1000) \\
= P(Y \leq \log 1000) \\
= P\left( Z \leq \frac{\log 1000 - 10}{2} \right) \\
= P(Z \leq -1.55) \\
= \Phi(-1.55) \\
= 0.0611
\]
```
